pullRequest.body:
... used in the definition of linearly disjointness.

Let `R` be a commutative ring, `S` be an `R`-algebra (not necessarily commutative).
Let `M` and `N` be `R`-submodules in `S`.

- `Submodule.mulMap`: the natural `R`-linear map `M ⊗[R] N →ₗ[R] S`
  induced by the multiplication in `S`, whose image is `M * N` (`Submodule.mulMap_range`).

- `Submodule.mulMap'`: the natural map `M ⊗[R] N →ₗ[R] M * N`
  induced by multiplication in `S`, which is surjective (`Submodule.mulMap'_surjective`).

- `Submodule.lTensorOne`, `Submodule.rTensorOne`: the natural isomorphism between
  `i(R) ⊗[R] N` and `N`, resp. `M ⊗[R] i(R)` and `M`, induced by multiplication in `S`,
  here `i : R → S` is the structure map. They generalize `TensorProduct.lid`
  and `TensorProduct.rid`, as `i(R)` is not necessarily isomorphic to `R`.

  Note that we use `⊥ : Subalgebra R S` instead of `1 : Submodule R S`, since the map
  `R →ₗ[R] (1 : Submodule R S)` is not defined directly in mathlib yet.

- `Submodule.mulLeftMap`: if `m : ι → M` is a family of elements, then there is an `R`-linear map
  from `ι →₀ N` to `S` which maps `{ n_i }` to the sum of `m_i * n_i`.

- `Submodule.mulRightMap`: if `n : ι → N` is a family of elements, then there is an `R`-linear map
  from `ι →₀ M` to `S` which maps `{ m_i }` to the sum of `m_i * n_i`.

---

> I hope these work? These comments also apply to `rTensorOne`.

Unfortunately, this file does not import the definition of `Subalgebra`. 😂 To minimize the dependency, I suggest not change them.

### PR summary [8e5609c15b](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12498/commits/8e5609c15bf484f8c53a68766cfec97e31f81998)

---

</details>

</details>

You can also use `(1 : Subalgebra R A)` if you prefer? Anyways the <_,_> was the only concern I had and this lgtm otherwise, and I'm happy to maintainer merge it once you think it is ready and CI passes.

> You can also use `(1 : Subalgebra R A)` if you prefer?

No, there is no instance `One (Subalgebra R A)` but only `One (Submodule R A)`. I think using `⊥ : Subalgebra R S` is OK; I just have to adjust code in my linearly disjoint PR.

> I'm happy to maintainer merge it once you think it is ready and CI passes.

Thanks. Now I'm satisfied (sort of) with current code.

Ok. Sorry again for the long wait!
Thanks!
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by erdOne.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9678761631/job/26703232324)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9678761631/job/26703232035)
I hope these work? These comments also apply to `rTensorOne`.
I think `Finsupp.lsum R fun i ↦ (m i).1 • N.subtype` is a more intuitive definition. Is there a reason why this definition is used?
And similarly, `Finsupp.lsum R fun i ↦ MulOpposite.op (n i).1 • M.subtype` for `mulRightMap`.
Let me try.

Ah, I remembered the reason: I need to express `mulLeftMap` as a composition of `mulMap` and a linear map which is injective or an isomorphism in the proof of equivalency of different definitions of linearly disjoint. So this property is essential.

But maybe we can use the new definition and state the old definition as `mulLeftMap_eq_mulMap_comp`?

And maybe the definition of these can go into the same file as `Finsupp.lsum`?
`mulLeftMap_eq_mulMap_comp` can be kept here.

> maybe the definition of these can go into the same file as `Finsupp.lsum`?

That cannot be done since `Algebra` is not imported in `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Finsupp`.

Or should we define a more general version of `mulLeftMap` which doesn't depend on `Algebra` and/or `Submodule`?

Maybe
```lean
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Finsupp

variable {R R' S} [CommSemiring R] [CommSemiring R'] [AddCommMonoid S]
  [Module R S] [Module R' S]
  [SMulCommClass R R' S] {N : Submodule R S}

noncomputable
def smulLeftSubtype {ι : Type*} (m : ι → R') : (ι →₀ N) →ₗ[R] S :=
  Finsupp.lsum R fun i ↦ (m i) • N.subtype
```

Thanks. I found that `[Algebra R S]` could be replace by `[Module R S] [SMulCommClass R S S]` So probably I can define `Submodule.mulLeftMap` in `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Finsupp`. Do you think your generalization `smulLeftSubtype` is still useful?

```suggestion
def lTensorOne' : (1 : Subalgebra R S) ⊗[R] N →ₗ[R] N :=
```
I think this is the same thing?

I don't think so; here I emphasis that it should be a `Submodule`. This map is used to prove that `(1 : Submodule R S)` is linearly disjoint to any other submodule.

By the way, for subalgebra I think it should be written as `(⊥ : Subalgebra R S)`.

Let me see if my proofs for linear disjoint can be adapted to this change.

This is coerced into a type so they are definitionally the same as long as the underlying subtype is?
And I think one and bot are the same thing for subalgebras?
No, there is no `(1 : Subalgebra R S)`.

I'm sorry, but my opinion is keep using `(1 : Submodule R S)` since this file is for submodule, not subalgebra. I'll mark this conversation as resolved. Feel free to unresolve it if there are further comments.

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem lTensorOne'_tmul (y : R) (n : N) :
    N.lTensorOne' (algebraMap R _ y ⊗ₜ[R] n) = y • n :=
```

```suggestion
  refine LinearEquiv.ofLinear N.lTensorOne' (TensorProduct.mk R (1 : Subalgebra R S) N 1⟩)
    (by ext; simp [lTensorOne']) (TensorProduct.ext' fun r n ↦ ?_)
```

I'm sorry, but my opinion is keep using `(1 : Submodule R S)` since this file is for submodule, not subalgebra. I'll mark this conversation as resolved. Feel free to unresolve it if there are further comments.

Sorry forgot about this PR, but my main concern is that the simp normal form should not be `⟨algebraMap R S y, algebraMap_mem y⟩` and `⟨1, one_le.1 (le_refl _)⟩`. A way to avoid this is to define `One (1 : Submodule R S)` and custom `algebraMapToOne`, but they will need some lemmas to set up, and I truly believe the easier way is to reuse the subalgbra API here.
OK I see your concern. Let me see if it's better to rename it to `(l|r)TensorBot` which uses `(⊥ : Subalgebra R S)`.
Done.
Similarly.
Should this be a simp lemma?
I marked them as simp lemmas. Hopefully they won't oversimplify things.

I think this is
```suggestion
  TensorProduct.lift <| (.mul R S).domRestrict₁₂ M N
```
or similar
Thanks, let me try later.
Do we really need to open `Classical`?
Done.

```suggestion
theorem mulMap_comp_map_inclusion {M' N' : Submodule R S} (hM : M' ≤ M) (hN : N' ≤ N) :
```
If you don't like it no problem.
Done.
I guess that here `M` and `N` can be implicit (surely also somewhere else). You can write `variable {M N} in` before the declaration if you don't want to change this everywhere.
Done.
Can you define this in term mode? (Proving the required `Prop` in tactic mode is of course fine.)
Done. (In fact it doesn't matter, since I've checked that `by refine LinearEquiv.ofLinear ...` actually compiles into `LinearEquiv.ofLinear ...`.)
Ah OK, I wasn't sure about that.
Same as above.
Done.
